newsitem.title: USA: Cotton use up, output woes keep prices high-ICAC.
newsitem.headline: Cotton use up, output woes keep prices high-ICAC.

text.p: Cotton mill use, moribund for a decade, will reach a record 19 million tonnes in 1996/97 despite high prices engendered by constrained crop output in Asia, the International Cotton Advisory Council said Monday.

In a monthly report, ICAC forecast cotton use at 19.04 million tonnes this marketing year after a decade in which use averaged 18.5 million tonnes. Further growth was expected -- 19.4 million tonnes in 1997/98 and 19.8 million the next year.
Most of the growth this year was in major cotton nations, including India, Pakistan and Turkey. Mill use also was up in China and the United States. Record use was seen in Mexico.
"Strong economic growth, population growth and consumer preferences for cotton products are the fundamentals driving world cotton use higher," the ICAC said.

Cotton yields were estimated at 575 kgs per hectare in 1996/97, down four percent from the record set in 1991/92. ICAC said the decline probably was due to specific problems in major nations -- pesticide resistance in eastern China, leaf curl virus in Pakistan and economic woes in Central Asia nations.
Tight stocks and large imports by China have held prices at above-average levels since 1993/94. Prices were pegged at 79 cents per lb in 1996/97, 82 cts in 1997/98. 81 cts in 1998/99.
